elements.content: NiO nanoparticles were in situ formed in a new metal–organic framework (MOF), [Ni3(pyip)2(HCOO)2(H2O)2] n [1; H2pyip = 5-(pyridine-4-yl)­isophthalic acid], which was characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, elemental analysis, thermogravimetric analysis, transmission electron microscopy, and powder and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The MOF 1 shows a 3,6-connected three-dimensional rtl topology network with a topological symbol of (4.62)2(42.610.83). Magnetic property studies showed that the combination of NiO nanoparticles within the magnetic MOF leads to the occurrence of long-range magnetic ordering below a critical temperature of 18 K.
elements.clean_text: NiO nanoparticles were in situ formed in a new metal-organic framework (MOF), [Ni3(pyip)2(HCOO)2(H2O)2] n  [1; H2pyip = 5-(pyridine-4-yl)isophthalic acid], which was characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, elemental analysis, thermogravimetric analysis, transmission electron microscopy, and powder and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The MOF 1 shows a 3,6-connected three-dimensional rtl topology network with a topological symbol of (4.62)2(42.610.83). Magnetic property studies showed that the combination of NiO nanoparticles within the magnetic MOF leads to the occurrence of long-range magnetic ordering below a critical temperature of 18 K.

elements.content: A magnetic nanoparticle and metal−organic framework (MOF) composite (NiO@MOF) was successfully synthesized. The combination of these two materials has a significant impact on the entire magnetic property. Long-range magnetic ordering with spontaneous magnetization below its critical temperature of 18 K with a hysteresis loop was observed.
elements.clean_text: A magnetic nanoparticle and metal-organic framework (MOF) composite (NiO@MOF) was successfully synthesized. The combination of these two materials has a significant impact on the entire magnetic property. Long-range magnetic ordering with spontaneous magnetization below its critical temperature of 18 K with a hysteresis loop was observed.

elements.content: Magnetic nanoparticles have shown great potential in catalysis, biomedical engineering, NMR imaging, information storage, environment separation, and magnetic fluids. When the size of a magnetic particle decreases toward dozens of nanometers, an unnatural magnetic behavior (superparamagnetism) will occur below the ordering temperature. For decades, a series of technologies have been developed to prepare the magnetic nanoparticles, such as coprecipitation, microemulsion, sol–gel processing, colloidal particle templating, and pyrolysis and displacement methods. However, the formation of magnetic nanoparticles using the above techniques still suffers from inhomogeneity in size and low-purity, high-energy consumption, and environmentally unfriendly waste, which are major obstacles for particle application. Therefore, it is a great challenge to develop a new synthesis method with lower cost and universal applicability to release the restrictions of special apparatus and synthetic conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Magnetic nanoparticles have shown great potential in catalysis, biomedical engineering, NMR imaging, information storage, environment separation, and magnetic fluids. When the size of a magnetic particle decreases toward dozens of nanometers, an unnatural magnetic behavior (superparamagnetism) will occur below the ordering temperature. For decades, a series of technologies have been developed to prepare the magnetic nanoparticles, such as coprecipitation, microemulsion, sol-gel processing, colloidal particle templating, and pyrolysis and displacement methods. However, the formation of magnetic nanoparticles using the above techniques still suffers from inhomogeneity in size and low-purity, high-energy consumption, and environmentally unfriendly waste, which are major obstacles for particle application. Therefore, it is a great challenge to develop a new synthesis method with lower cost and universal applicability to release the restrictions of special apparatus and synthetic conditions.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a new generation of crystalline porous materials built by inorganic nodes and organic linkers. MOFs have aroused wide attention because of their diverse physical properties in view of the selected functional structural frameworks. The porous frameworks offer promising applications in gas sorption, chemical sensing, electrical energy storage, proton conduction, luminescence, catalyst, and magnetism. There are diverse techniques for crystallization of the MOFs, including slow evaporation of the solvents, diffusion of the reagents, hydrothermal or solvothermal reactions, etc. It is well-known that hydrothermal or solvothermal reaction is a operative method for the synthesis of MOFs by virtue of their simplicity, efficiency, and environmental friendliness.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a new generation of crystalline porous materials built by inorganic nodes and organic linkers. MOFs have aroused wide attention because of their diverse physical properties in view of the selected functional structural frameworks. The porous frameworks offer promising applications in gas sorption, chemical sensing, electrical energy storage, proton conduction, luminescence, catalyst, and magnetism. There are diverse techniques for crystallization of the MOFs, including slow evaporation of the solvents, diffusion of the reagents, hydrothermal or solvothermal reactions, etc. It is well-known that hydrothermal or solvothermal reaction is a operative method for the synthesis of MOFs by virtue of their simplicity, efficiency, and environmental friendliness.

elements.content: Combining magnetic nanospecies and MOFs can lead to not only new composite materials but also enhanced magnetic properties. For example, the combination of the single-molecule magnet (SMM) moiety [MnIII(salen)­(H2O)]2 2+ and the oxalate ferromagnetic framework affords a magnetic composite with an increased coercive field of the hysteresis loop; when the SMM [Mn12O12(O2CCH3)16(OH2)4] (Mn12Ac) was loaded in a mesoporous MOF, [Al­(OH)­(SDC)] n (H2SDC = 4,4′- stilbenedicarboxylic acid), a significantly enhanced thermal stability can be achieved without loss of the original SMM property; the magnetization behavior of Dy2 SMM nodes embedded in a lanthanide-based MOF can be fine-tuned via guest exchange. The main challenge in this aspect is how to combine these two types of materials in a rational chemical manner for enhanced stability and physical property.
elements.clean_text: Combining magnetic nanospecies and MOFs can lead to not only new composite materials but also enhanced magnetic properties. For example, the combination of the single-molecule magnet (SMM) moiety [MnIII(salen)(H2O)]2 2+ and the oxalate ferromagnetic framework affords a magnetic composite with an increased coercive field of the hysteresis loop; when the SMM [Mn12O12(O2CCH3)16(OH2)4] (Mn12Ac) was loaded in a mesoporous MOF, [Al(OH)(SDC)] n  (H2SDC = 4,4'- stilbenedicarboxylic acid), a significantly enhanced thermal stability can be achieved without loss of the original SMM property; the magnetization behavior of Dy2 SMM nodes embedded in a lanthanide-based MOF can be fine-tuned via guest exchange. The main challenge in this aspect is how to combine these two types of materials in a rational chemical manner for enhanced stability and physical property.

elements.content: In this contribution, we reported the in situ formation of NiO nanoparticles within a MOF, namely, [Ni3(pyip)2(HCOO)2(H2O)2] n [1; H2pyip = 5-(pyridine-4-yl)­isophthalic acid], to give a NiO@MOF composite. Detailed characterizations including powder and single-crystal X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed to study the structure and magnetic property for this NiO@MOF composite. The combination of magnetic NiO nanoparticles and the framework led to a long-range magnetic ordering below 18 K and hysteresis loops.
elements.clean_text: In this contribution, we reported the in situ formation of NiO nanoparticles within a MOF, namely, [Ni3(pyip)2(HCOO)2(H2O)2] n  [1; H2pyip = 5-(pyridine-4-yl)isophthalic acid], to give a NiO@MOF composite. Detailed characterizations including powder and single-crystal X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed to study the structure and magnetic property for this NiO@MOF composite. The combination of magnetic NiO nanoparticles and the framework led to a long-range magnetic ordering below 18 K and hysteresis loops.

elements.content: All analytical-grade chemicals were obtained commercially and used without further purification. A PerkinElmer elemental analyzer was adopted for analysis of carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy with a KBr pellet was performed on a Bruker TENOR 27 spectrophotometer in the range of 400–4000 cm–1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out in a Labsys NETZSCH TG 209 Setaram apparatus with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in an inert atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained using a Rigaku D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. TEM images were recorded using a Tecnai G2-F20 transmission electron microscope at 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a PHI5000 Versa probe. Magnetic measurements were carried out using a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS VSM magnetometer, with the direct-current (dc) applied fields ranging from −7 to +7 T and the measuring temperature ranging from 2 to 300 K.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Remarks

All analytical-grade chemicals were obtained commercially and used without further purification. A PerkinElmer elemental analyzer was adopted for analysis of carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy with a KBr pellet was performed on a Bruker TENOR 27 spectrophotometer in the range of 400-4000 cm-1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out in a Labsys NETZSCH TG 209 Setaram apparatus with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in an inert atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained using a Rigaku D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. TEM images were recorded using a Tecnai G2-F20 transmission electron microscope at 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a PHI5000 Versa probe. Magnetic measurements were carried out using a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS VSM magnetometer, with the direct-current (dc) applied fields ranging from -7 to +7 T and the measuring temperature ranging from 2 to 300 K.

elements.content: An Agilent Technologies SuperNova single-crystal diffractometer with graphite-monocromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω-scan mode was employed in the measurement of the single-crystal data of 1 at 128 K. The crystal structure was solved by direct methods (SHELXS-97). All non-H atoms are refined with anisotropic thermal parameters by full-matrix least-squares techniques using SHELXL-97. The H atoms are fixed by using a riding mode and treated isotropically with the program package Olex2. CCDC 1483774 for 1 is offered in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, containing the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

An Agilent Technologies SuperNova single-crystal diffractometer with graphite-monocromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω-scan mode was employed in the measurement of the single-crystal data of 1 at 128 K. The crystal structure was solved by direct methods (SHELXS-97). All non-H atoms are refined with anisotropic thermal parameters by full-matrix least-squares techniques using SHELXL-97. The H atoms are fixed by using a riding mode and treated isotropically with the program package Olex2. CCDC 1483774 for 1 is offered in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, containing the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.

elements.content: The chemicals of H2pyip (24.3 mg), Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O (58.2 mg), LiOH (4.2 mg), 4 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and 1 mL of water (H2O) were placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave liner. The sealed reactor was heated to 160 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure and then cooled to ambient temperature at a cooling rate of 3 °C/h to yield long strip green crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. The crystals were washed with DMF and dried slowly in air (68% yield based on H2pyip). Calcd for C28H20N2Ni3O14: C, 42.83; H, 2.55; N, 3.57. Found: C, 42.46; H, 2.63; N, 3.77. IR (KBr): 3245­(w), 2839­(m), 1624(s), 1507­(w), 1447­(m), 1390(s), 1227­(m), 1068(s), 1026­(m), 843­(m), 774(s), 727(s), 646(s), 470­(w) cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of NiO@MOF

The chemicals of H2pyip (24.3 mg), Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (58.2 mg), LiOH (4.2 mg), 4 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and 1 mL of water (H2O) were placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave liner. The sealed reactor was heated to 160 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure and then cooled to ambient temperature at a cooling rate of 3 °C/h to yield long strip green crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. The crystals were washed with DMF and dried slowly in air (68% yield based on H2pyip). Calcd for C28H20N2Ni3O14: C, 42.83; H, 2.55; N, 3.57. Found: C, 42.46; H, 2.63; N, 3.77. IR (KBr): 3245(w), 2839(m), 1624(s), 1507(w), 1447(m), 1390(s), 1227(m), 1068(s), 1026(m), 843(m), 774(s), 727(s), 646(s), 470(w) cm-1.

elements.content: The host structure of 1 was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, which was crystallized in monoclinic space group P21/c (Table S1). As shown in a, the coordination sphere of the central Ni2 that is located at an inversion center is completed by four O atoms from two bridging carboxylate groups, two bridging bidentate formates, and two O atoms from μ2-η1:η2-carboxylate groups with bond lengths of 2.011(3)–2.795(2) Å. The terminal Ni1 atoms have similar coordination spheres, occupied by three O atoms from μ2-η1:η2-carboxylate groups, one O atom from a bridging bidentate formate, one O atom from a H2O molecule, and one N atom from the pyridyl ring of pyip2–. The Ni1–O bond lengths vary from 2.016(7) to 2.188(8) Å, and the Ni–N bond length is 2.044(2) Å. Three octahedral NiII ions are connected to a linear trinuclear secondary building unit (SBU) with a Ni···Ni distance of 3.513(6) Å. The SBUs are further linked to each other through pyip2– ligands to form a one-dimensional (1D) Ni3-cluster-based chain (b). Then the chains are further connected via the ligands into an infinite 3,6-connected three-dimensional (3D) rtl topology framework with a topological symbol of (4.62)2(42.610.83), rationalized by TOPOS 3.2, if the Ni3 cluster and pyip2– ligands are simplified into the 6- and 3-connected nodes, respectively (c). Selected bond lengths and angles are summarized in Table S2, which are in the normal range for NiII complexes. It is noted that the formate ions were created by the in situ hydrolysis of DMF.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures

The host structure of 1 was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, which was crystallized in monoclinic space group P21/c (Table S1). As shown in a, the coordination sphere of the central Ni2 that is located at an inversion center is completed by four O atoms from two bridging carboxylate groups, two bridging bidentate formates, and two O atoms from μ2-η1:η2-carboxylate groups with bond lengths of 2.011(3)-2.795(2) Å. The terminal Ni1 atoms have similar coordination spheres, occupied by three O atoms from μ2-η1:η2-carboxylate groups, one O atom from a bridging bidentate formate, one O atom from a H2O molecule, and one N atom from the pyridyl ring of pyip2-. The Ni1-O bond lengths vary from 2.016(7) to 2.188(8) Å, and the Ni-N bond length is 2.044(2) Å. Three octahedral NiII ions are connected to a linear trinuclear secondary building unit (SBU) with a Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni distance of 3.513(6) Å. The SBUs are further linked to each other through pyip2- ligands to form a one-dimensional (1D) Ni3-cluster-based chain (b). Then the chains are further connected via the ligands into an infinite 3,6-connected three-dimensional (3D) rtl topology framework with a topological symbol of (4.62)2(42.610.83), rationalized by TOPOS 3.2, if the Ni3 cluster and pyip2- ligands are simplified into the 6- and 3-connected nodes, respectively (c). Selected bond lengths and angles are summarized in Table S2, which are in the normal range for NiII complexes. It is noted that the formate ions were created by the in situ hydrolysis of DMF.

elements.content: (a) Ni3 cluster in 1. Color code: C, gray; O, red; N, blue; Ni, green. H atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) 1D Ni3-cluster-based chain of 1. (c) 3D topological schematic of 1 (green nodes for Ni3 clusters and gray nodes for pyip2– ligands).
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Ni3 cluster in 1. Color code: C, gray; O, red; N, blue; Ni, green. H atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) 1D Ni3-cluster-based chain of 1. (c) 3D topological schematic of 1 (green nodes for Ni3 clusters and gray nodes for pyip2- ligands).

elements.content: The PXRD pattern was well-consistent with the simulated one from the single-crystal diffraction data (Figure S3). To exclude the effect from nickel metal, XPS was employed. The peaks located at binding energies of 853.9 and 871.6 eV with a separation of 17 eV are attributable to Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 of the NiII ion (Figure S5). The TGA curve represents a weight loss evolution with increasing temperature. A weight loss of 4.76% in the range of 110–310 °C is in accordance with the leaving of two coordinated H2O molecules (calcd value, 4.57%); the following weight loss is ascribed to the loss of coordinated formate ions and the decomposition of organic components, and the remaining weight is related to the formation of NiO (testing value, 29.02%; calcd value, 28.82%; Figure S4).
elements.clean_text:
PXRD, TGA, and XPS

The PXRD pattern was well-consistent with the simulated one from the single-crystal diffraction data (Figure S3). To exclude the effect from nickel metal, XPS was employed. The peaks located at binding energies of 853.9 and 871.6 eV with a separation of 17 eV are attributable to Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 of the NiII ion (Figure S5). The TGA curve represents a weight loss evolution with increasing temperature. A weight loss of 4.76% in the range of 110-310 °C is in accordance with the leaving of two coordinated H2O molecules (calcd value, 4.57%); the following weight loss is ascribed to the loss of coordinated formate ions and the decomposition of organic components, and the remaining weight is related to the formation of NiO (testing value, 29.02%; calcd value, 28.82%; Figure S4).

elements.content: Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurement of 1 was carried out at a dc field of 1000 Oe in the temperature range of 2–300 K. χM T and χM versus T plots are shown in a. The room-temperature χM T is 4.91 cm3 mol–1 K, which is much higher than the spin-only value of 3.0 cm3 mol–1 K for three noninteracting octahedral NiII ions, and values that mixed the angular momenta from excited states by spin–orbit coupling were considered. Upon cooling, χM T decreased slowly to 4.33 cm3 mol–1 K at 75 K, and then it increased rapidly to the maximum value of 13.98 cm3 mol–1 K at 16 K. Upon further lowering of the temperature, χM T decreased sharply to 3.14 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K, caused by either zero-field splitting or the contribution from antiferromagnetic coupling interactions between NiII trimeric units.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurement of 1 was carried out at a dc field of 1000 Oe in the temperature range of 2-300 K. χM T and χM versus T plots are shown in a. The room-temperature χM T is 4.91 cm3 mol-1 K, which is much higher than the spin-only value of 3.0 cm3 mol-1 K for three noninteracting octahedral NiII ions, and values that mixed the angular momenta from excited states by spin-orbit coupling were considered. Upon cooling, χM T decreased slowly to 4.33 cm3 mol-1 K at 75 K, and then it increased rapidly to the maximum value of 13.98 cm3 mol-1 K at 16 K. Upon further lowering of the temperature, χM T decreased sharply to 3.14 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K, caused by either zero-field splitting or the contribution from antiferromagnetic coupling interactions between NiII trimeric units.

elements.content: (a) Plots of χM and χM T versus T for the NiO@MOF composite at 1000 Oe field. (b) Field dependence of magnetization. Inset: Plots of the dM/dH versus H at 2 K for the NiO@MOF composite.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Plots of χM and χM T versus T for the NiO@MOF composite at 1000 Oe field. (b) Field dependence of magnetization. Inset: Plots of the dM/dH versus H at 2 K for the NiO@MOF composite.

elements.content: M versus H plots for 1 at 2 K are shown in b. The magnetization increases continuously up to the maximum value of 4.6 Nβ at 60 kOe, which is smaller than the saturation value of 6 Nβ expected for three noninteracting NiII ions due to the occurrence of magnetic anisotropy, crystal-field effect, and low-lying excitation states of NiII ions. The derivative of the magnetization shows that the critical field at 2 K is extracted as 5000 G estimated from dM/dH value (inset of b).
elements.clean_text: M versus H plots for 1 at 2 K are shown in b. The magnetization increases continuously up to the maximum value of 4.6 Nβ at 60 kOe, which is smaller than the saturation value of 6 Nβ expected for three noninteracting NiII ions due to the occurrence of magnetic anisotropy, crystal-field effect, and low-lying excitation states of NiII ions. The derivative of the magnetization shows that the critical field at 2 K is extracted as 5000 G estimated from dM/dH value (inset of b).

elements.content: Zero-field-cooled (ZFC) and field-cooled (FC) magnetization susceptibilities were measured at 50 Oe, as shown in . The magnetizations of the FC curves increase steadily with decreasing temperature, and no maximum was observed. Below 18 K, the magnetic susceptibilities at 50 Oe increase quickly in the FC case and start to diverge from the ZFC measurement, indicative of the possibility of spontaneous magnetization, while there is no above-mentioned phenomenon similar to the magnetic behaviors of critical doped samples in the established Mn3 and Co3 system. In addition, in the case of the Prussian Blue structural analogue K­{Ni­[Au­(CN)2]3} with NiO nanoparticles yielded by hydrothermal synthesis at the selected temperatures (125, 135, and 165 °C), the bifurcated temperatures of the ZFC and FC curves are 20, 22.75, and 22.75 K, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Zero-field-cooled (ZFC) and field-cooled (FC) magnetization susceptibilities were measured at 50 Oe, as shown in . The magnetizations of the FC curves increase steadily with decreasing temperature, and no maximum was observed. Below 18 K, the magnetic susceptibilities at 50 Oe increase quickly in the FC case and start to diverge from the ZFC measurement, indicative of the possibility of spontaneous magnetization, while there is no above-mentioned phenomenon similar to the magnetic behaviors of critical doped samples in the established Mn3 and Co3 system. In addition, in the case of the Prussian Blue structural analogue K{Ni[Au(CN)2]3} with NiO nanoparticles yielded by hydrothermal synthesis at the selected temperatures (125, 135, and 165 °C), the bifurcated temperatures of the ZFC and FC curves are 20, 22.75, and 22.75 K, respectively.

elements.content: FC/ZFC curves of the NiO@MOF composite at 50 Oe.
elements.clean_text: 3  FC/ZFC curves of the NiO@MOF composite at 50 Oe.

elements.content: To study the nature of the possible phase transition at the divergence temperature, the alternating-current (ac) magnetic susceptibilities for NiO@MOF were collected at 99 and 997 Hz under zero dc field (a). The peaks of frequency-independent in-phase (χ′) and out-of-phase (χ″) versus T plots reveal the occurrence of long-range magnetic ordering below 18 K. This long-range ordering leads to a shuttlelike hysteresis loop at 2 K with a coercive field (H c) of 860 Oe and a remanence of 0.170 Nβ (b).
elements.clean_text: To study the nature of the possible phase transition at the divergence temperature, the alternating-current (ac) magnetic susceptibilities for NiO@MOF were collected at 99 and 997 Hz under zero dc field (a). The peaks of frequency-independent in-phase (χ') and out-of-phase (χ") versus T plots reveal the occurrence of long-range magnetic ordering below 18 K. This long-range ordering leads to a shuttlelike hysteresis loop at 2 K with a coercive field (H c) of 860 Oe and a remanence of 0.170 Nβ (b).

elements.content: (a) ac susceptibilities of the NiO@MOF composite measured at 99 and 997 Hz under zero dc field. (b) Hysteresis loop of the NiO@MOF composite at 2 K.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) ac susceptibilities of the NiO@MOF composite measured at 99 and 997 Hz under zero dc field. (b) Hysteresis loop of the NiO@MOF composite at 2 K.

elements.content: Indeed, the analytical data from elemental analysis, TGA, XPS, and the PXRD data failed to give evidence for NiO nanoparticles because of the very small amount of NiO nanoparticles. We can confirm the existence of NiO nanoparticles within the MOF by the magnetic data and TEM images. According to the crystal structure of the MOF 1, especially the high-room-temperature χM T, the above magnetic properties should not belong to the host framework itself but from the combination of the NiO nanoparticle and the framework. Moreover, we can clearly observe the dark circular profile of nanoparticles in the scope of 5–7 nm by TEM ().
elements.clean_text: Indeed, the analytical data from elemental analysis, TGA, XPS, and the PXRD data failed to give evidence for NiO nanoparticles because of the very small amount of NiO nanoparticles. We can confirm the existence of NiO nanoparticles within the MOF by the magnetic data and TEM images. According to the crystal structure of the MOF 1, especially the high-room-temperature χM T, the above magnetic properties should not belong to the host framework itself but from the combination of the NiO nanoparticle and the framework. Moreover, we can clearly observe the dark circular profile of nanoparticles in the scope of 5-7 nm by TEM ().

elements.content: (a) Optical image of crystal samples of 1. (b) TEM image of NiO nanoparticles of a powder sample of 1. (c) Partially enlarged TEM image of NiO nanoparticles of a powder sample of 1. Inset: Selected area electron diffraction pattern of a powder sample of 1. (d) TEM image of NiO particles with a crystalline interplanar spacing of 2.89 Å corresponding to the (012) planes of NiO (JCPDS 89-3080).

(d) TEM image of NiO particles with a crystalline interplanar spacing of 2.89 Å corresponding to the (012) planes of NiO (JCPDS 89-3080).

elements.content: Several approaches to combining two different magnetic composites into one singular material have been realized recently. For example, Mn12Ac@CYCU-3 was formed by encapsulating the prototypical SMM Mn12Ac into the mesoporous MOF [Al­(OH)­(SDC)] n (CYCU-3) host, exhibiting an obvious hysteresis loop and a significantly enhanced thermal stability from the rigid framework. The impaction of the SMM moiety [MnIII(salen)­(H2O)]2 2+ inside a ferromagnetic bimetallic oxalate-based network offers a very interesting magnetic composite. The hybrid compound shows a larger magnetization hysteresis loop below 1 K than that of the SMMs and the oxalate ferromagnetic lattice. Researches have targeted a nanoparticles@MOFs composite. For instance, in 2008, superparamagnetic NiO nanoparticles formed by a hydrothermal method had a positive effect on the magnetic behavior of the 3D paramagnetic K­{Ni­[Au­(CN)2]3} lattice. Additionally, small-sized particles of NiO with superparamagnetic behavior tend to exhibit interesting magnetic properties, such as low-temperature hysteresis below a blocking temperature and divergence between the ZFC and FC curves. In a nutshell, nanoparticles@MOFs can lead to the presence of associated novel magnetic properties, such as long-range magnetic ordering, spin canting, spin frustration, and so on, which is an alternative system of the combination of SMMs and MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Several approaches to combining two different magnetic composites into one singular material have been realized recently. For example, Mn12Ac@CYCU-3 was formed by encapsulating the prototypical SMM Mn12Ac into the mesoporous MOF [Al(OH)(SDC)] n  (CYCU-3) host, exhibiting an obvious hysteresis loop and a significantly enhanced thermal stability from the rigid framework. The impaction of the SMM moiety [MnIII(salen)(H2O)]2 2+ inside a ferromagnetic bimetallic oxalate-based network offers a very interesting magnetic composite. The hybrid compound shows a larger magnetization hysteresis loop below 1 K than that of the SMMs and the oxalate ferromagnetic lattice. Researches have targeted a nanoparticles@MOFs composite. For instance, in 2008, superparamagnetic NiO nanoparticles formed by a hydrothermal method had a positive effect on the magnetic behavior of the 3D paramagnetic K{Ni[Au(CN)2]3} lattice. Additionally, small-sized particles of NiO with superparamagnetic behavior tend to exhibit interesting magnetic properties, such as low-temperature hysteresis below a blocking temperature and divergence between the ZFC and FC curves. In a nutshell, nanoparticles@MOFs can lead to the presence of associated novel magnetic properties, such as long-range magnetic ordering, spin canting, spin frustration, and so on, which is an alternative system of the combination of SMMs and MOFs.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have prepared and characterized NiO nanoparticles in situ generated in a MOF framework via the solvothermal method. The combination of NiO nanoparticles and magnetic MOFs can significantly affect the overall magnetic properties of this composite. Magnetic studies show that long-range magnetic ordering with a critical temperature of 18 K occurred in this NiO@MOF composite. This work illustrated that the MOF-coated magnetic nanoparticle can be generated in situ via the powerful hydrothermal/solvothermal method if appropriate raw materials and reaction conditions are selected. Further studies on this topic could be expanded to the development of a new synthetic method and a targeted system to control the size and morphology of the nanoparticles and properties for practical applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, we have prepared and characterized NiO nanoparticles in situ generated in a MOF framework via the solvothermal method. The combination of NiO nanoparticles and magnetic MOFs can significantly affect the overall magnetic properties of this composite. Magnetic studies show that long-range magnetic ordering with a critical temperature of 18 K occurred in this NiO@MOF composite. This work illustrated that the MOF-coated magnetic nanoparticle can be generated in situ via the powerful hydrothermal/solvothermal method if appropriate raw materials and reaction conditions are selected. Further studies on this topic could be expanded to the development of a new synthetic method and a targeted system to control the size and morphology of the nanoparticles and properties for practical applications.

elements.content:

cln_elements.content: The chemicals of H2pyip (24.3 mg), Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O (58.2 mg), LiOH (4.2 mg), 4 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and 1 mL of water (H2O) were placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave liner. The sealed reactor was heated to 160 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure and then cooled to ambient temperature at a cooling rate of 3 °C/h to yield long strip green crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. The crystals were washed with DMF and dried slowly in air (68% yield based on H2pyip). Calcd for C28H20N2Ni3O14: C, 42.83; H, 2.55; N, 3.57. Found: C, 42.46; H, 2.63; N, 3.77. IR (KBr): 3245­(w), 2839­(m), 1624(s), 1507­(w), 1447­(m), 1390(s), 1227­(m), 1068(s), 1026­(m), 843­(m), 774(s), 727(s), 646(s), 470­(w) cm–1.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of NiO@MOF

The chemicals of H2pyip (24.3 mg), Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (58.2 mg), LiOH (4.2 mg), 4 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and 1 mL of water (H2O) were placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave liner. The sealed reactor was heated to 160 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure and then cooled to ambient temperature at a cooling rate of 3 °C/h to yield long strip green crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. The crystals were washed with DMF and dried slowly in air (68% yield based on H2pyip). Calcd for C28H20N2Ni3O14: C, 42.83; H, 2.55; N, 3.57. Found: C, 42.46; H, 2.63; N, 3.77. IR (KBr): 3245(w), 2839(m), 1624(s), 1507(w), 1447(m), 1390(s), 1227(m), 1068(s), 1026(m), 843(m), 774(s), 727(s), 646(s), 470(w) cm-1.

cln_elements.content:
The PXRD pattern was well-consistent with the simulated one from the single-crystal diffraction data (Figure S3). To exclude the effect from nickel metal, XPS was employed. The peaks located at binding energies of 853.9 and 871.6 eV with a separation of 17 eV are attributable to Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 of the NiII ion (Figure S5). The TGA curve represents a weight loss evolution with increasing temperature. A weight loss of 4.76% in the range of 110–310 °C is in accordance with the leaving of two coordinated H2O molecules (calcd value, 4.57%); the following weight loss is ascribed to the loss of coordinated formate ions and the decomposition of organic components, and the remaining weight is related to the formation of NiO (testing value, 29.02%; calcd value, 28.82%; Figure S4).

Magnetic Properties

Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurement of 1 was carried out at a dc field of 1000 Oe in the temperature range of 2–300 K. χM T and χM versus T plots are shown in a. The room-temperature χM T is 4.91 cm3 mol–1 K, which is much higher than the spin-only value of 3.0 cm3 mol–1 K for three noninteracting octahedral NiII ions, and values that mixed the angular momenta from excited states by spin–orbit coupling were considered. Upon cooling, χM T decreased slowly to 4.33 cm3 mol–1 K at 75 K, and then it increased rapidly to the maximum value of 13.98 cm3 mol–1 K at 16 K. Upon further lowering of the temperature, χM T decreased sharply to 3.14 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K, caused by either zero-field splitting or the contribution from antiferromagnetic coupling interactions between NiII trimeric units.
cln_elements.clean_text:
PXRD, TGA, and XPS

The PXRD pattern was well-consistent with the simulated one from the single-crystal diffraction data (Figure S3). To exclude the effect from nickel metal, XPS was employed. The peaks located at binding energies of 853.9 and 871.6 eV with a separation of 17 eV are attributable to Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 of the NiII ion (Figure S5). The TGA curve represents a weight loss evolution with increasing temperature. A weight loss of 4.76% in the range of 110-310 °C is in accordance with the leaving of two coordinated H2O molecules (calcd value, 4.57%); the following weight loss is ascribed to the loss of coordinated formate ions and the decomposition of organic components, and the remaining weight is related to the formation of NiO (testing value, 29.02%; calcd value, 28.82%; Figure S4).

Magnetic Properties

Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurement of 1 was carried out at a dc field of 1000 Oe in the temperature range of 2-300 K. χM T and χM versus T plots are shown in a. The room-temperature χM T is 4.91 cm3 mol-1 K, which is much higher than the spin-only value of 3.0 cm3 mol-1 K for three noninteracting octahedral NiII ions, and values that mixed the angular momenta from excited states by spin-orbit coupling were considered. Upon cooling, χM T decreased slowly to 4.33 cm3 mol-1 K at 75 K, and then it increased rapidly to the maximum value of 13.98 cm3 mol-1 K at 16 K. Upon further lowering of the temperature, χM T decreased sharply to 3.14 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K, caused by either zero-field splitting or the contribution from antiferromagnetic coupling interactions between NiII trimeric units.

metadata.title:
In Situ Generation of NiO Nanoparticles in a Magnetic
Metal–Organic Framework Exhibiting Three-Dimensional Magnetic
Ordering
